reviewText: This fine documentary produced by The History Channel describes the events leading up to and the attack on Pearl Harbor in vivid detail.  Drawing on testimonies of famous World War II historians such as Richard Frank and Donald M. Goldstein (who co-authored Gordon Prange's definitive "At Dawn We Slept"), this documentary brings to life the events of December 7, 1941.  The documentary covers the entire Pearl Harbor attack, as well as the diplomatic negotiations between Japan and the United States.  Japanese and American survivors give their input as well, from Japanese pilots recalling the textbook-perfect execution of their attack to American servicemen fighting to survive the nightmarish inferno of battle.I believe that oral history is the best way to learn about history or a specific historical event, and this documentary contains excellent testimonies from both Japanese and American survivors.  The Japanese describe what it was like to actually travel all the way across the Pacific undetected to make their attack, while the Americans describe the horrors of battle, from bodily injuries to the death of a friend, or being trapped inside a ship and given up for dead when they were really alive.  These testimonies are one of the high points of the documentary.I was also impressed with the computer generated rendition of the sinking of the U.S.S. Arizona.  The graphics are excellent, and I learned a great deal more about the loss of the Arizona from this rendition.  For example, the rendition shows that the first bomb that struck the Arizona did relatively little damage, but the second bomb is the one that ultimately destroyed the ship.Also included in this fine set is a documentary of Admiral Chester W. Nimitz.  From his early days growing up in Texas until the outbreak of World War II, this video looks at the life of perhaps America's greatest military commander.  Included is a narration of all of the major campaigns of the Pacific War and how through his excellent choices of subordinates, Nimitz's navy managed to destroy the Japanese fleet.I highly recommend this fine video set.  The actual combat footage is first-rate, the narration is superb, and the input from both historians and survivors make the documentary quite enjoyable to watch.  This is a fine set and includes all of the essential information on the attack on Pearl Harbor and our ultimate victory over the Japanese.
Title: N/A

reviewText: But without a doubt, worth the money. Pearl Harbor will be big this summer with the release of Ben Afleck's big screen beefcake-fest of the same name, so it might inspire your kids to watch just some of the story behind the Hollywood treatment. Showing that wars don't just happen, it explains the steady build up of a world heading non-stop to global conflict. Seeing pictures of some of the survivors as young men and hearing their stories as told today, both Japanese and American, adds a very touching human element to a story that we all know the ending. Also, spending time on what happened on December 8 and shortly after helps fill in the picture of an isolationist nation thrust in a rage into a war. Disk Two offers a wonderful look at the man that was responsible for hold Japan at bay while America rebuilt in the Pacific, Chester Nimitz. Another bonus program,"America's Five Star Heros" is familiar, but no less enlightening. All in all, a great choice for the history buff.
summary: Familiar Stuff To A History Channel Viewer

reviewText: Before we go on, I want to explain something. When I say Japan/Japanese in this article, I am not meaning Japan/Japanese as in today. I am also not speaking of its citizens at all, whether in the past or present, with the exception of one citizen who was interviewed. When I say Japan/Japanese, I am ONLY talking about the Japanese government in power during WWII. Just as we would not denounce today's Germans but we would when discussing the Nazis instead. There is a very clear difference and I want this to be flatly stated before moving on.All that said, this is NOT a two-disc set about Pearl Harbor. This is one disc which contains one documentary which is instead entitled TORA, TORA, TORA: The True Story of Pearl Harbor. While it is in two parts, it is ONLY on disc one. The second disc has no direct relationship with the Pearl Harbor attack, but is instead about Nimitz and his leadership of the pacific fleet. Already, you have been tricked into believing it is a two-disc set about Pearl Harbor, when it is very much NOT. This is your first clue that something is amiss.After eagerly popping in the DVD, I noticed something within the first few minutes that grated on my nerves. For whatever reason, the narrator repeats "as a result" time and time again. I lost count after six times, I believe. It reminds me of the incessant "Jack!" that Kate Winslet yelled throughout Titanic. It's not the narrator's fault (just like it is not Kate Winslet's fault), but it is the writers fault, which is another warning bell. Simply put, sloppy writing is never a good thing in a documentary.My first suspension of disbelief however was when the narrator actually says that Japan's reason for its invasion of China was that Japan felt Asians should be ruled by Asians and not by European colonies. Sounds good on the surface because everyone would agree with the logic in that, after all that's what our own country was borne from, until you remember the other part... such as the Japanese slaughtering Chinese women and children. Sure, that was so much better than colonial rule, right?Of course this does not mean that they do not touch on the subject of the Japanese attacks on Chinese women and children, because they do, for a second.As they discuss the effects of the a-bomb, they air an interview of a Japanese man by the name of Zenji Abe, who nefariously proclaims that Japan only attacked the military at Pearl and it was unfair for America to target civilians. He even goes further to say that for the Japanese civilian deaths, America violated international treaties.While a part of that may be true, though hotly debated by some, there are still so many things wrong with what the wretched man says, that I hardly know where to begin. Add to that the History channel's audacity to even include it in a documentary such as this and you have a very badly tarnished documentary on your hands.What bothers me most about this is not the stupidly naive accusation Mr. Abe spews forth, but that many viewers will watch this to learn more about the Pearl Harbor attack. This video will falsely give an impression that America reaped what it sowed, when in fact it is quite the other way around. The Japanese government is solely responsible for all the effects of the war onto itself; to include the a-bomb. End of story.For the learner, here are a few facts this documentary plotted to leave out:* Japan did kill civilians in Hawaii, it was not only friendly fire.* Japan raped Chinese women and children in the streets, in front of their families. Do NOT forget the AND children part; eight-year-olds were raped in front of their families. Mr. Abe conveniently forgot about this part.Surprised?* Japan tortured many American POWs in the same way that the Germans tortured the Jews. This is a fact that is not even in most history books, but Google it for yourself. This is something no one wants to bring up, but why? This too would be in violation of international treaties. This was not a rumor, but pure documented fact.* Japan knew the consequences of war, but elected to make war anyway, thus putting their civilians at risk. Yes, they leave that out.So now I had to ask myself: why would the History Channel add an interview with a man who clearly had no idea what he was talking about? There is only one conclusion. They wanted viewers to believe it to be true. Shame on them.Anotherdocumentary(source is below) sums it up very well, "Japan, broken, defeated, awash in blood spilled in a war of its own design, would look back at December 7th, 1941 as the day that destroyed its dream of empire and conquest."That right there is the end result of Japan's entire situation in WWII. It was all about greed without any regard for life, liberty, justice nor any happiness whatsoever. On the contrary, they wanted what they wanted and they wanted to destroy anyone who got in their way of getting it.This isn't to say that this documentary never pointed out that Japan was, in fact, greedy for China's resources, but it is clear that this documentary makes America out as a bad guy here. They are clearly defending the WWII Japanese government, who deserves absolutely no defense, whatsoever, for its actions, period. Japan reaped what it sowed. End of story.For all of these reasons, I could not possibly recommend this to anyone with a straight face. I would have given it one star, but I'll give it another star (=2) for the interviews of victims from Pearl Harbor. However, I would instead highly recommend the documentary I touched on above,Attack on Pearl Harbor: A Day of Infamy; it has some of the same victims in interviews as well.
summary: Missing key facts and twists the truth.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a DVD set which is quite well done, but I find the packaging a bit misleading. There are three DVDs included, only one of which is specifically about Pearl Harbor, the other two are biographies of Douglas MacArthur and Chester Nimitz. Obviously these two figures are crucial to an understanding of the Pacific war, but are really tangential to Pearl Harbor. This was the sole reason that I deducted a star from the package.The Pearl Harbor DVD is quite well done and combines historical and contemporary footage and interviews with some rather early generation computer graphics to produce a slick and powerful telling of the story of the Pearl Harbor attack and its context in history.The biography of MacArthur is fascinating. I have always found MacArthur to be a brilliant but arrogant General, and this DVD reinforced that appraisal. This production helped me appreciate some of MacArthur's strengths more than I had before, but also helped me understand the psychological side of him which led to his aloofness and arrogance.The Nimitz biography is wonderful. I have always regarded Nimitz as the greatest of the Pacific commanders. I think Halsey was the better battlefield commander, but Nimitz was an amazing motivator and organizer, and a great, compassionate man. This DVD made me appreciate Nimitz even more that I previously did, and I think anyone interested in naval history would love it.In total, this is a very good production, with excellent use of archive and current footage and with insightful interviews. I think anyone interested in World War Two would be thrilled with this set, even if it isn't exclusively about Pearl Harbor.
summary: Great Documentaries On The Pacific War
Title: N/A

reviewText: A good documentary, but with all of the Pearl Harbor documentary material out there, why did the creators choose to include  a documentary DVD on Chester Nimitz? This set should have been called "War In The Pacific" or something. But, the history is accurate and the footage is good. I would recommend this. It would have been great if they had one DVD about the attack, one dvd about Kimmell, and one DVD about Yamamoto. That would have made this collection stand out from the others! History Channel, ARE YOU READING THIS?

reviewText: This is a great documentary. It has all of the information you'd need on the events surrounding the "Day of Infamy." It also has a great look at the real life heroes of the events, and the look at their movie counterparts from the epic summer blockbuster PEARL HARBOR. For World War II historians and movie buffs! Worth the price! Grade: A+
summary: INTERESTING AND EXCITING! A GREAT DOCUMENTARY FILM!
